column4: hey guys how come when i turn 'swap on' in my partition editor the next time i boot my computer it's not automatically turned on? i have to turn it on each time...how do i make it so it stays on automatically each time i boot?
add a line for it to /etc/fstab
can't i do it through the partition editor thougH?
no
there is nothing wrong with "manually" editing config files
you can reinstall ubuntu. That will generate a new /etc/fstab
well i see the swap in the file, it's /dev/sda3  so why doesn't it automatically turn on when i boot my system?
I agree with bavardage.
because there is no way for any "automatic" procedure in ubuntu to know whether you want to use that swap partition for ubuntu.
it could be dedicated swap space for another OS on your disk, or it could be a pure hibernate rather than a swap partition.
just add the swap line to /etc/fstab, it's not even worth discussion automatiing that.
can you tell me if this file is in order, my swap space is /dev/sda3, not i haven't touched this file, this is how it is...yet still it appears to be 'off' after a boot: http://www.pastie.org/267335
please run 'sudo blkid' and pastebin that, too
http://www.pastie.org/267340
your swap space UUID has changed. 'gksudo gedit /etc/fstab', edit line 10 and replace the UUID with the new one: UUID="c73eb5f8-0739-4e30-a348-036f9e43d834"
wow thanks
does that make sense?
yes i moved partitions around recently
if you want to, you can remove the entire UUID reference and refer to the swap partition by its device name instead, /dev/sda3
ok cool ill try that
out of interest why does it use the UUID if the /dev/device_name thing is so much easier?

if you change your partitions, the device name can change. The UUID stays the same, until you reformat the partition. In general, the UUID change has made things more robust -- your situation is the exception
